results.title: Ecology of a hot spring: life at high temperatures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Uses the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park as a laboratory for the study of organisms that can survive the effects of high temperatures. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Distribution of plants and animals
results.creator_credit: William Peltz, John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Studies plant and animal ecology. Traces the various factors which influence the distribution and survival of animals in a given geographical area. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Community
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Defines the ecological community as a complex network of interrelationships among a group of plants and animals adapted to the same general physical conditions, food chains and food webs.

results.title: Getting better (A)
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Larry Lucas, Michael Le Moignan, Australian Film Commission and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
The life expectancy of Australian Aborigines is twenty years less than white life expectancy. But things are changing. Aboriginal people are taking control of their own health care. They are trying to combine the best elements of Western medicine with traditional remedies.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Yuri Sokol, Larry Lucas, Michael Le Moignan, Australian Film Commission and Corroboree Films

results.title: Eora corroboree
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Yuri Sokol, Michael Le Moignan and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
For 40,000 years, the Aboriginal people of Australia had a rich and diverse culture, which sprang from and reflected their way of life and beliefs. Their culture was not written, but spoken, sung and performed. Since the coming of white man their culture has very nearly been destroyed. Aboriginal playwright, screenwriter and director Bob Merritt believes that a resurgence of Aboriginal culture is possible and in 1984 set up the Eora Centre for the Visual and Performing Arts in Redfern to offer young Aboriginals a comprehensive education in their traditional arts. Looks at the role of the Eora Centre and interviews some of its teachers and students.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barbara A. Chobocky, Yuri Sokol, Michael Le Moignan and Corroboree Films

results.title: Echinoderms: sea stars and their relatives
results.brief_description:
Episode of series “Biology program. Unit 3. Animal life”
Describes the characteristics of the echinoderm body plan and shows how it adapted for locomotion, respiration, digestion and reproduction. Includes examples of the five classes of echinodeerms.
Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Fish embryo from fertilization to hatching
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 3. Animal life”.
Illustrates how fish eggs are fertilised in a stream, then traces the development of the zygote from the first cell cleavage to the formation of a young fish. Suitable for upper secondary level.
